titleStmt.title: Notes conferr'd, or, A dialogue betwixt the groaning board and a Jesuite demonstrating the ambiguous humour of the one, and curiosity of the other.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: NOTES CONFERR'D: OR, A DIALOGUE BETWIXT THE Groaning Board, AND A Jeſuite: DEMONSTRATING THE Ambiguous Humour of the one, and CURIOSITY of the other.
LONDON, Printed for R: Shuter, in the Year 1682.

div.head: A DIALOGUE betwixt the Groaning-Board, and a Ieſuite.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: BY your leave Gentlemen, I underſtand you have that wonderful Plank to be ſeen here, that is ſo nois'd throughout the whole Town, for Repartee.

p.hi: O Sir, the Town does too much honour it; Repartee! Alas, ſee it's but a board: It has indeed with Hums and Haws, delivered ſome bold Truths.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I have a great Curioſity to propoſe a few Queſtions to it; which by your leave, and the good Companies, may be divertive and advantagious, if you permit.

p.hi: With all my Heart Sir, there lies the Oracle; Firſt, let me tell you, that as for matters of State, thoſe things have been demanded, and reſolv'd, to the ſatisfaction of all the Town.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, if you preſcribe me Rules, you wrong my fancy; beſides, Oracles are not always in humour: and many a fair opportunity has been Couch'd under Ambiguous Words, and loſt for want of an Expoſiture.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.p: Ambiguous Words! You think it's a cheat I ſuppoſe? Mr. Andrew, clap on the Irons.

p.hi: There's an Ambitious Hum-drum for you Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: 'T • s ſo indeed; forbear good Mr. Andrew, whilſt I make uſe of your Maſter's Liberty, to propound a few queſtions to it.

sp.speaker: Andrew.
sp.p: With all my Heart, pray Gentlemen expect but little flattery; the Plank was not bred in London, nor at Barn-Elmes neither.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Where ever thou was bred, it was not Nature, but Miracle, that gave thee language; and that thy Inſpiration be not loſt, or Dully-ſing'd away by Mercinary hands, I do Conjure thee by that power that gave thee Tongue, to tell me what's the cauſe of theſe Elaborate Groans.

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: O hooo, I know thou art a friend to Rome, I ſmell thy Beads, I can deny thee nothing. In Henery's Days I bore a lofty top: the Workman's envy, and the Proud Ax ground, my ſollid body then devided was, and ſeaſon'd, to be Carv'd into an Alter: but Henry then declin'd, and I lay by, till Mary and St. Bonner, turned me o're: 'Twas then that Holy Man deviſed a Rack, and I thought worthy, for the Bleſſed Work; But Mary was not fit for our lewd days, ſo we reſign'd her with our tears to Heaven: the Good Old Man bleſſ'd all he had begun. But Beſs being Crown'd, poor Bonner was no more: the Conſecrated Engine ſhe deſtroy'd; But Bonner, vertuous Bonner, choſe at his Death, rather then leave the Earth before the Glorious Work of Rome was done, to leave in me a Tranſmigrated Soul.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No more, I durſt have ſworne he had been in Heaven; I'le have ten thouſand Maſſes Sung for him.

p.hi: Ten Thouſand, and Ten Thouſand, are in vain.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What an unfortunate man was I, to make this Publick? The Biſhop I am ſure underſtood Latin, he could have anſwered me there.

p.hi: But you were kinder to this Auditory, then at your Chappel; yet let them have fair play for their mony: and ſo pray go on Sir, if you deſire any more from me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Ave Maria, Plena Gratia.

p.hi: Ah, ah, ah, forbear good Sir, the Biſhop never ordain'd you his Chaplain; If you will ſing him a good Gentile Maſs now, he will laugh at you when you have done.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: This muſt be the Devil that anſwers; I'le fright him out, and torture him, for making uſe of the Reverend Biſhop's name: there Sir, there's ſome Holy Water for you; how like you that?

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: I, marry Sir, I grant you have reaſon now; half a pint of this, and two quarts of Brandy, will make a Capuſheen ſwe ••• like a Jeſuit; Pray how can you afford this a Gallon.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: O never queſtion the Rates, you ſhall not want, there's more for you.

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: Now, now, a little of your Extream Ʋnction quickly, quickly, and kick me into Purgatory preſently; what have you none? a little from the Lamp, 'tis all one, and has ſerv'd a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Detracting Spirit, 'twas then of the Lamp of the Lady Loretta's, which has the ſame operation.

p.hi: I know it, and begin to feel ſomething like a turn of Reformation.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Reformation, I am abus'd, a Biſhop of our Church and talk of Reformation; no, no, this is the Spirit of ſome Schiſmatick Lutherine or Calviniſt; but I want not charity, though you do belief; there's more Water.

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: O hold, good Father, I do confeſs I was the unfortunate Luther.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: O Sir, are you ſo? what think you of marrying a profeſt Nun, and to deny your faith to ſerve your pleaſure, and then defending Sezeme that has ſpread over the Chriſtian World.

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: A Schiſm Father, the Monarch ſaid, let Faith defend it ſelf; I lookt upon the Maid with vertuous thoughts, and fear'd her Innocence might not ſecure that part I lov'd (her Soul) against the Serpentine and bloody Ieſuit, your Patron; Ignatius Lyales did not Head a Schiſm, but was in open Rebellion ſure, when he propoſed ways to his Holineſs, for depoſing or Murdering of Princes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Prithee no more of that, 'tis all forgiven; Ignatius was to blame, and Belarmin was Raſh, but they are Sainted, i'le divert this, ſpeak without malice, where is St. Coleman now?

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: Why? with St. Oliver, he ſays there was a Trick put upon him for his life, and Swears, There's no Truth in Man.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: St. VVhitebread, where is he?

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: St. Peters and he are comparing of Notes, who moſt deluded the People.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: St. Pickering, Good-man, where is he?

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: St. Reveleack and he are hot in Diſpute, whether he that attempts, or he that does the great Act, is moſt Honourable.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I am ſorry there ſhould be ſuch Bickquerings amongſt brave Spirits; but where is my old Friend St. Plunket?

p.hi: He ſtands to it yet, that he is as Innocent as the Child unborn, and though two of his Impeachers which are there, ſwore all was true.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Who are they pray?

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: St. Bedloe, and St. Turbervile.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I, thoſe are Saints indeed; you have St. Colledge too, I ſuppoſe, pray what ſays he?

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: Why faith, he ſpeaks a great deal of Reaſon in his Cold fit, he Curſes the Ignoramus Jury, that would not ſend his Lord and Patroon to him; he ſwears he has ſuch a Plot, that M—th ſhould be King, were he but here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Then God preſerve his Lordſhip, ſaid I; Green, Berry, and Hill, how do they?

sp.speaker: Board.
sp.p: Very merry, they laught when they heard that T— was Pillar'd, but ſaid he deſerv'd it, for meddleing with what did not concern him; and as for Mr. P— they heartily forgave him. Now Sir, I have this requeſt to you, that you would give my Master your Receiv againſt Worms and Maggets, which may preſerve me as well as Joſeph's Breeches: I have ſeen three pair of them, as freſh as thoſe you ware; and to be friends Merry Andrew, with a hundred or two of nails of the Croſs, I know there is ſeveral thouſands of them: the Croſs it ſelf, you'l grant, is in a thouſand pieces, though its all whole in ſeveral places too; The Virgins Milk, nor theſe, are nothing to the Spaniſh and Mexicon Miracles; But now I deſire a greater of you, (which is) to leave me without further trouble, and give Room to Company, which your Impertinence has hindred.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Farewel Jeſuit.

sp.speaker: Andrew.
sp.p: How! is he a Jeſuit? let's ſecure him, we ſhall have Ten Pounds for Hanging of him.

p.hi: 'Twere well got, but I queſtion that mightily.
